items.title: Pakistan declares 'open war' against Afghanistan

items.content: #Pakistan conducted airstrikes in Kabul and three other Afghan provinces overnight between Thursday and Friday, authorities in #Afghanistan said, as the former's defence minister said that the countries were now in "open war".

items.title: Civilians flee fighting after Pakistan bombs Afghan cities
items.standfirst: After an Afghan cross-border attack on Thursday night, Pakistan carried out overnight strikes on Kabul and declared what it called an “open war” with Afghanistan, sending civilians in border areas fleeing to safety.
items.content: After an Afghan cross-border attack on Thursday night, Pakistan carried out overnight strikes on Kabul and declared what it called an “open war” with Afghanistan, sending civilians in border areas fleeing to safety.

items.title: Pakistan-Afghanistan conflict: 'Localised clashes still going on'
items.standfirst: Localised clashes are still continuing along the Afghanistan-Pakistan border while Taliban officials say Pakistani aircraft continue to fly over Afghanistan's territory, reports France 24's correspondent Shahzaib Wahlah, following Pkaistan's bombing of major cities in Afghanistan including the capital Kabul on Friday.
items.content: Localised clashes are still continuing along the Afghanistan-Pakistan border while Taliban officials say Pakistani aircraft continue to fly over Afghanistan's territory, reports France 24's correspondent Shahzaib Wahlah, following Pkaistan's bombing of major cities in Afghanistan including the capital Kabul on Friday.

items.title: Pakistan declares state of ‘open war’ after bombing major Afghan cities
items.standfirst: Wave of strikes comes after Taliban forces attack Pakistani border troops following earlier action from IslamabadPakistan has bombed major cities in Afghanistan including the capital, Kabul, with Islamabad’s defence minister declaring that the hostile neighbours were in a state of “open war” as a cycle of retaliatory attacks escalated further.Witnesses in Kabul and Kandahar, the southern Afghan city, reported explosions and jets overhead until dawn, while the Taliban government said later that Pakistani surveillance aircraft were still flying over Afghanistan. Continue reading...

items.title: Pakistan’s ‘open war’ on Afghanistan follows years of tensions
items.standfirst: The Pakistani government declared “open war” on the Taliban authorities on Friday after an Afghan offensive launched on Thursday on its border led Islamabad to bomb Kabul in retaliation. But these tensions between the two neighboring countries are not new; they have been going on for years and have been exacerbated since the Taliban returned to power in Kabul in 2021.
items.content: The Pakistani government declared “open war” on the Taliban authorities on Friday after an Afghan offensive launched on Thursday on its border led Islamabad to bomb Kabul in retaliation. But these tensions between the two neighboring countries are not new; they have been going on for years and have been exacerbated since the Taliban returned to power in Kabul in 2021.

items.title: What's behind Pakistan-Afghanistan conflict?
items.standfirst: Pakistan bombed major cities in Afghanistan including the capital Kabul on Friday, with Islamabad's defence minister declaring the neighbours at "open war". It comes after months of tit-for-tat clashes, with Islamabad accusing Afghanistan of failing to act against militant groups that carry out attacks in Pakistan, which the Taliban government denies. France 24’s Douglas Herbert takes a closer look at the causes of the conflict.
items.content: Pakistan bombed major cities in Afghanistan including the capital Kabul on Friday, with Islamabad's defence minister declaring the neighbours at "open war". It comes after months of tit-for-tat clashes, with Islamabad accusing Afghanistan of failing to act against militant groups that carry out attacks in Pakistan, which the Taliban government denies. France 24’s Douglas Herbert takes a closer look at the causes of the conflict.

items.title: Pakistan bombs Kabul after intensifying border clashes with Afghanistan
items.standfirst: Escalation of violence between the volatile neighbours makes a Qatar-mediated ceasefire appear increasingly shakyPakistan bombed Afghanistan’s capital of Kabul and two other provinces on Friday, hours after a cross-border attack, the latest escalation of deadly violence between the volatile neighbours who signed a Qatar-mediated ceasefire in 2025.Following months of tit-for-tat clashes, Afghan forces attacked Pakistani border troops on Thursday night in what the Taliban government said was retaliation for earlier deadly airstrikes. Continue reading...
items.content: Escalation of violence between the volatile neighbours makes a Qatar-mediated ceasefire appear increasingly shakyPakistan bombed Afghanistan’s capital of Kabul and two other provinces on Friday, hours after a cross-border attack, the latest escalation of deadly violence between the volatile neighbours who signed a Qatar-mediated ceasefire in 2025.Following months of tit-for-tat clashes, Afghan forces attacked Pakistani border troops on Thursday night in what the Taliban government said was retaliation for earlier deadly airstrikes. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Bill Clinton at Epstein deposition: "I saw nothing, and I did nothing wrong"

items.title: Bill Clinton at Epstein deposition: "I saw nothing, and I did nothing wrong"
items.standfirst: Former President Bill Clinton denied any knowledge of Jeffrey Epstein's crimes in an opening statement before the House Oversight Committee in New York.
items.content: Former President Bill Clinton denied any knowledge of Jeffrey Epstein's crimes in an opening statement before the House Oversight Committee in New York.

items.title: Bill Clinton questioned for over 5 hours on Jeffrey Epstein
items.standfirst: Former President Bill Clinton appeared on Friday before the House Oversight Committee for a closed-door deposition about his relationship with Jeffrey Epstein. Clinton said he "never witnessed during our limited interactions any indication of what was truly going on." CBS News legal reporter Katrina Kaufman has more.
items.content: Former President Bill Clinton appeared on Friday before the House Oversight Committee for a closed-door deposition about his relationship with Jeffrey Epstein. Clinton said he "never witnessed during our limited interactions any indication of what was truly going on." CBS News legal reporter Katrina Kaufman has more.

items.title: Bill Clinton testifies about ties to Jeffrey Epstein: ‘I saw nothing, and I did nothing wrong’ – live
items.standfirst: Former president tells House oversight committee he is cooperating in the Epstein investigation out of love of country and desire for victims to healSign up for the Breaking News US email to get newsletter alerts direct to your inboxJames Comer, the chair of the House oversight committee, said the committee’s list of questions for Bill Clinton grew longer after Hillary Clinton’s deposition yesterday, where she deferred a host of questions to her husband.“So we already had a big portfolio of questions for him, and that increased yesterday,” Comer said at a press conference outside the building where the closed-door deposition was set to begin shortly. Continue reading...

items.title: Bill Clinton faces grilling from lawmakers over his connections to Jeffrey Epstein
items.standfirst: Former President Bill Clinton is testifying Friday before members of Congress investigating convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, answering for his connections to the disgraced financier from more than two decades ago. The closed-door deposition in Chappaqua, comes a day after Clinton's wife, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, sat with lawmakers for her own deposition. France 24's Jessica Le Masurier has the latest from Chappaqua.
items.content: Former President Bill Clinton is testifying Friday before members of Congress investigating convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, answering for his connections to the disgraced financier from more than two decades ago. The closed-door deposition in Chappaqua, comes a day after Clinton's wife, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, sat with lawmakers for her own deposition. France 24's Jessica Le Masurier has the latest from Chappaqua.

items.title: Epstein files: Clinton hearings 'political theatre to distract public from Trump'
items.standfirst: Former President Bill Clinton is testifying Friday before members of Congress investigating convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, a day after Clinton's wife, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, sat with lawmakers for her own deposition. However, according to Ian Reifowitz, history professor at SUNY-Empire State University, the hearings a mainly “political theatre” designed to distract the American public from Epstein’s links with Donald Trump.
items.content: Former President Bill Clinton is testifying Friday before members of Congress investigating convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, a day after Clinton's wife, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, sat with lawmakers for her own deposition. However, according to Ian Reifowitz, history professor at SUNY-Empire State University, the hearings a mainly “political theatre” designed to distract the American public from Epstein’s links with Donald Trump.

items.title: Takeaways from Hillary Clinton's deposition. And, Paramount outbids for Warner Bros.
items.standfirst: Hillary Clinton says the questioning in a closed-door deposition with the House Oversight Committee's Epstein investigation was repetitive. And, Paramount has outbid Netflix for Warner Bros.
items.content: Hillary Clinton says the questioning in a closed-door deposition with the House Oversight Committee's Epstein investigation was repetitive. And, Paramount has outbid Netflix for Warner Bros.(Image credit: Charly Triballeau)

items.title: Anthropic refuses to bend to Pentagon on AI safeguards
items.standfirst: A public showdown between the Trump administration and Anthropic is hitting an impasse as military officials demand the artificial intelligence company bend its ethical policies by Friday or risk damaging its business. Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei drew a sharp red line 24 hours before the deadline, declaring his company “cannot in good conscience accede” to the Pentagon’s final demand to allow unrestricted use of its technology.
items.content: A public showdown between the Trump administration and Anthropic is hitting an impasse as military officials demand the artificial intelligence company bend its ethical policies by Friday or risk damaging its business. Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei drew a sharp red line 24 hours before the deadline, declaring his company “cannot in good conscience accede” to the Pentagon’s final demand to allow unrestricted use of its technology.

items.title: Why is Anthropic refusing the Pentagon? #world

clusters.title: U.S.-Iran deal is "within our reach," Omani mediator says

items.title: U.S.-Iran deal is "within our reach," Omani mediator says
items.standfirst: Negotiators from the U.S. and Iran have made "substantial progress" toward a deal to curb Iran's nuclear program, Omani Foreign Minister Badr Albusaidi told CBS News on Friday.
items.content: Negotiators from the U.S. and Iran have made "substantial progress" toward a deal to curb Iran's nuclear program, Omani Foreign Minister Badr Albusaidi told CBS News on Friday.

items.title: Oman's foreign minister says U.S.-Iran nuclear "deal is within our reach"
items.standfirst: Omani foreign minister Badr bin Hamad Albusaidi, a key mediator in the US-Iran nuclear talks, tells "Face the Nation" moderator Margaret Brennan that he's confident "a peace deal is within our reach" between the U.S. and Iran as negotiators meet over Tehran's nuclear program. He also said, "I don't think any alternative to diplomacy is going to solve this problem." Albusaidi met with Vice President JD Vance in Washington, D.C., on Friday.
items.content: Omani foreign minister Badr bin Hamad Albusaidi, a key mediator in the US-Iran nuclear talks, tells "Face the Nation" moderator Margaret Brennan that he's confident "a peace deal is within our reach" between the U.S. and Iran as negotiators meet over Tehran's nuclear program. He also said, "I don't think any alternative to diplomacy is going to solve this problem." Albusaidi met with Vice President JD Vance in Washington, D.C., on Friday.

clusters.title: NASA redirects Artemis moon mission program, postponing a planned astronaut landing

items.title: NASA redirects Artemis moon mission program, postponing a planned astronaut landing

clusters.title: Trump advisers scramble to justify US military intervention in Iran

items.title: Trump advisers scramble to justify US military intervention in Iran
items.standfirst: Tehran’s ICBMs cannot currently reach the US, experts say, and White House has claimed its nuclear programme has been destroyedSign up for the Breaking News US email to get newsletter alerts in your inboxDonald Trump’s likely casus belli for an attack on Iran – which would be the largest US intervention since the Iraq war – is fraught with contradictions, and his top advisers have been left to cover for him as the White House makes the case for intervention.In his State of the Union address this week, Trump alleged that Iran posed a direct threat to the US and that the country was “working to build missiles that will soon reach the United States of America”. But that claim has not been backed up with evidence by the White House or the Pentagon, and US intelligence reports from just last year say that it would take Iran 10 years to develop an intercontinental ballistic missile that could reach the US. Continue reading...
items.content: Tehran’s ICBMs cannot currently reach the US, experts say, and White House has claimed its nuclear programme has been destroyedSign up for the Breaking News US email to get newsletter alerts in your inboxDonald Trump’s likely casus belli for an attack on Iran – which would be the largest US intervention since the Iraq war – is fraught with contradictions, and his top advisers have been left to cover for him as the White House makes the case for intervention.In his State of the Union address this week, Trump alleged that Iran posed a direct threat to the US and that the country was “working to build missiles that will soon reach the United States of America”. But that claim has not been backed up with evidence by the White House or the Pentagon, and US intelligence reports from just last year say that it would take Iran 10 years to develop an intercontinental ballistic missile that could reach the US. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump suggests US could carry out ‘friendly takeover’ of Cuba
items.standfirst: As tensions between two countries reach new highs, US president says regime is ‘talking with us’Sign up for the Breaking News US email to get newsletter alerts in your inboxDonald Trump has suggested the US could carry out a “friendly takeover” of Cuba as tensions between Washington and Havana reach a new high following the capture of Venezuela’s Nicolás Maduro.As he left the White House for a campaigning event in Texas on Friday, Trump said: “The Cuban government is talking with us. They’re in a big deal of trouble.” Continue reading...
items.content: As tensions between two countries reach new highs, US president says regime is ‘talking with us’Sign up for the Breaking News US email to get newsletter alerts in your inboxDonald Trump has suggested the US could carry out a “friendly takeover” of Cuba as tensions between Washington and Havana reach a new high following the capture of Venezuela’s Nicolás Maduro.As he left the White House for a campaigning event in Texas on Friday, Trump said: “The Cuban government is talking with us. They’re in a big deal of trouble.” Continue reading...

items.title: Marco Rubio orders US officials to stop commentary that could strain Iran talks
items.standfirst: Exclusive: memo came after Mike Huckabee’s remarks about Israel sparked alarm inside White HouseSign up for the Breaking News US email to get newsletter alerts direct to your inboxThe US secretary of state Marco Rubio told ambassadors in the Middle East to stop making public comments that could inflame tensions and undermine Donald Trump’s pressure on Iran to relinquish its capacity to produce a nuclear weapon, according to a memo obtained by the Guardian.“Given rising tensions in the region, Chiefs of Mission and embassies at addressee posts must refrain from public statements, interviews, or social media activity that could in any way inflame regional audiences, prejudice sensitive political issues, or complicate US relationships,” the cable said. Continue reading...
items.content: Exclusive: memo came after Mike Huckabee’s remarks about Israel sparked alarm inside White HouseSign up for the Breaking News US email to get newsletter alerts direct to your inboxThe US secretary of state Marco Rubio told ambassadors in the Middle East to stop making public comments that could inflame tensions and undermine Donald Trump’s pressure on Iran to relinquish its capacity to produce a nuclear weapon, according to a memo obtained by the Guardian.“Given rising tensions in the region, Chiefs of Mission and embassies at addressee posts must refrain from public statements, interviews, or social media activity that could in any way inflame regional audiences, prejudice sensitive political issues, or complicate US relationships,” the cable said. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump ‘not happy’ with Iran situation and says military force is still an option
items.standfirst: US president accuses Tehran of failing to ‘negotiate in good faith’ over its nuclear programmeSign up for the Breaking News US email to get newsletter alerts direct to your inboxDonald Trump says he has not made a final decision on whether to launch strikes on Iran but is “not happy” with the situation and military force – including regime change – remains an option.The remarks came at the White House on Friday after talks between the US and Iran on Tehran’s nuclear programme ended inconclusively, with a suggestion that further discussions would be held next week. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump says 'not happy' with Iran talks, but undecided on possible military action
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump said on Friday he was "not happy" with the way Iran was negotiating in talks with the US, but had not yet made a "final decision" on whether the US would launch military action against Tehran. His comments came as the US advised its non-emergency embassy staff to leave Israel "due to safety risks".
items.content: US President Donald Trump said on Friday he was "not happy" with the way Iran was negotiating in talks with the US, but had not yet made a "final decision" on whether the US would launch military action against Tehran. His comments came as the US advised its non-emergency embassy staff to leave Israel "due to safety risks".

items.title: US-Iran nuclear talks end without a deal as threat of war grows
items.standfirst: Mediators say more talks to be held next week but no clear evidence two sides any closer on uranium enrichmentHigh-stakes talks between the US and Iran over the future of Tehran’s nuclear programme ended on Thursday without a deal, as the White House weighs a military operation that would mark its largest intervention in the Middle East in decades.The Iranian foreign minister, Abbas Araghchi, claimed “good progress” had been made at the talks and Omani mediators predicted negotiations would reconvene at a technical level next week in Vienna. Continue reading...
items.content: Mediators say more talks to be held next week but no clear evidence two sides any closer on uranium enrichmentHigh-stakes talks between the US and Iran over the future of Tehran’s nuclear programme ended on Thursday without a deal, as the White House weighs a military operation that would mark its largest intervention in the Middle East in decades.The Iranian foreign minister, Abbas Araghchi, claimed “good progress” had been made at the talks and Omani mediators predicted negotiations would reconvene at a technical level next week in Vienna. Continue reading...

clusters.neutral_headline: Israel Allows Aid Groups to Continue

items.title: Israel’s top court allows aid groups facing Gaza ban to continue working
items.standfirst: The Supreme Court ruling comes after Israel said it would ban 37 aid groups from Gaza for failing to follow new rules.
items.content: The Supreme Court ruling comes after Israel said it would ban 37 aid groups from Gaza for failing to follow new rules.

items.title: Israel's Supreme Court allows aid groups facing govt ban to keep working in Gaza
items.standfirst: Israel’s top court on Friday froze a government ban on 37 foreign aid organisations operating in Gaza and the occupied West Bank, issuing an interim order that allows the groups to continue their work while the court considers a final ruling.
items.content: Israel’s top court on Friday froze a government ban on 37 foreign aid organisations operating in Gaza and the occupied West Bank, issuing an interim order that allows the groups to continue their work while the court considers a final ruling.

Israel had planned to ban groups

clusters.title: Six planets due to parade across night sky in rare celestial spectacle

items.title: Six planets due to parade across night sky in rare celestial spectacle
items.standfirst: Jupiter, Saturn, Venus, Mercury, Neptune and Uranus will all be visible at same time in curved line across skySix planets will parade across the sky this weekend in a rare celestial spectacle, experts have said.For the next few days, Jupiter, Saturn, Venus, Mercury, Neptune and Uranus will all be visible at the same time in the night sky – although binoculars or a telescope will be needed to spot the latter two planets. Continue reading...
